revised_title: Seismic Refraction Shooting in the Eastern Atlantic: Exploring Oceanic Layers and Sedimentary Structures
tldr: This article describes a new method of seismic refraction shooting in the deep ocean, using hydrophones and sono-radio buoys to study the structure of the ocean floor. The authors discovered layers of sedimentary and crystalline rock, with varying thicknesses and velocities, providing insights into the geology and history of the area. This method expanded the understanding of deep ocean structures and contributed to the development of future deep-sea exploration techniques.
